I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) has requested technical 
assistance  (TA)  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  help  prepare  the  Kunming 
Qingshuihai Water Supply Project. The TA is included in the 2006–2008 country strategy and 
program update.1 The Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC in March 2006, and reached an 
understanding with the Government on the impact and outcome, scope, cost and financing, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Kunming is the capital of Yunnan Province, which is in southwestern PRC. Yunnan 
Province is bordered to the south by Lao People’s Democratic Republic and Viet Nam, to the 
west by Myanmar, to the east by Guangxi and Guizhou provinces, PRC, and to the north by 
Sichuan and Tibet provinces. As the PRC seeks to forge closer trading links with its neighbors 
in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Yunnan Province—and consequently Kunming—
assumes  greater  strategic  significance  as  a  regional  center.  Centrally  located  within  the 
province, Kunming is a city of 5.78 million people, including approximately 2.46 million who 
reside within the main urban area. As the provincial capital, Kunming is the political, commercial, 
and cultural center of the province, as well as an important transportation hub. 
 
3.  Kunming comprises 1 county-level city, 5 districts, and 8 counties. As in many large PRC 
cities,  rapid  economic  growth  over  the  past  20  years  has  increased  the  stress  on  the 
environment. In particular, the quality of water in Lake Dianchi has fallen to class V2 or below, 
which means it is no longer suitable as a water source for urban needs. Based on United 
Nations criteria, Kunming is classified as a city with a severe shortage of water resources. The 
loss of Lake Dianchi as a useable water resource has made the shortage worse.  
 
4.  Kunming has a well-prepared and thorough development plan, with a principal planning 
horizon of 2020. The city’s main development objectives are to sustain a high rate of economic 
growth as the main means for improving the quality of residents’ lives, and to reduce the poverty 
that still exists for some urban and rural residents. Further, rapid gross domestic product growth 
is needed to create jobs for the continuing migration of people from rural areas to the urban 
areas.  
 
5.  The proposed project will address the projected water shortages in the fast-developing 
New Airport Economic Zone and the Eastern Development Zone of Kunming City. These are 
identified  as  newly  urbanized  areas  under  the  Kunming  City  master  plan.  The  Kunming 
municipal government (KMG) has included the proposed project in its 11th City Five-Year Plan 
for 2006–2010, which was approved recently. In July 2005, the Yunnan Water Conservancy and 
Hydropower Survey, Design and Research Institute prepared a draft feasibility study report 
(FSR). The Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) is financing a separate water 
supply project (Kunming Water Supply Project), which is under construction. The JBIC Project 
will  provide  additional water  to  the  northern part  of  the  main  urban  area.  ADB  previously

provided  support  for  the  development  of  urban  water  resources  in  the  PRC.  The  project 
objectives are similar to the Harbin Water Supply Project,3 which is being implemented, and the 
earlier Dalian Water Supply Project.4 
 
6.  One of ADB’s strategic objectives in the PRC is to improve the environment and protect 
natural resources. The proposed project is consistent with ADB’s strategy. In support of the 
strategy,  policy  dialogue  will  continue  on  (i)  integrated  urban  development  planning,  (ii) 
integrated water resources management, (iii) water sector institutional arrangements, (iv) water 
pricing as a demand management tool, (v) private sector involvement, and (vi) tariffs and 
financial sustainability. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA will prepare a project to improve the living and health conditions of Kunming, as 
well as facilitate economic development in the city, through the provision of reliable water 
supplies. The project will assist the Government in providing 104 million cubic meters (m3) of 
water annually from Qingshuihai Lake, some 100 kilometers (km) north of the main urban area 
of Kunming. The new water resources will benefit the New Airport Economic Zone (62 million m3 
a year), the Eastern Development Zone (35 million m3 a year), and Xundian County (7 million 
m3 a year). About 6.4 million residents in these areas are expected to benefit from 24-hour 
water supply assured by the project. Further, the project will help the Government achieve the 
Millennium  Development  Goal  for  environmental  sustainability  (Goal  7),  and  to  halve  the 
proportion of people without sustainable access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation by 
2015 (Target 10).The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will review and analyze the medium- and long-term sector plans for water supply 
and wastewater management in Kunming Municipality. This review will be conducted within the 
context of the principles of integrated water resources management and the Kunming City 
master plan. The TA will recommend improvements in the sector plans to make them more 
responsive to the development objectives of Kunming, and to improve water services to all 
residents, including vulnerable groups. The scope of works included in the project proposal and 
draft FSR prepared by KMG will be analyzed in the context of the Kunming City Masterplan, and 
the sector plans and policies. The TA will focus on (i) integrated water resources management; 
(ii) urban poverty reduction, social protection, and resettlement policies; (iii) tariff reform to 
recover full costs of operation and maintenance, as well as depreciation; (iv) use of tariffs as a 
water demand management tool; (v) enterprise reform and corporate governance; (vi) urban 
and industrial water conservation; (vii) effluent recycling and introduction of clean production 
techniques; and (viii) private sector involvement.  
 
9.  The TA also will review the feasibility of the proposed project, covering (i) preparation of 
preliminary engineering designs and cost estimates, (ii) assessment of financial and economic 
viability  and  sustainability,  (iii)  assessment  of  environmental  and  social  soundness,  and 
(iv) development of a design and monitoring framework and implementation arrangements. In

3
addition, the TA will (i) review the proposed project implementation arrangements, (ii) assess 
the need for the Executing Agency and implementing agencies to strengthen financial and 
managerial capacity, (iii) prepare an effective operation and maintenance plan for the project 
facilities, and (iv) develop project-specific education and training programs. The TA also will 
review potential environmental impacts, including (i) water balance, and the pattern of water use 
in the catchments whose water will be diverted to Qingshuihai Lake; (ii) effects on downstream 
areas that will have less water; and (iii) secondary pollution resulting from additional wastewater 
in the urban areas. KMG’s assessment on alternatives will be reviewed in view of technical 
appropriateness; cost effectiveness; and social, environmental, and resettlement impacts. The 
locations  of  proposed  reservoir  and  construction  sites  will  be  determined  carefully,  and 
measures  to  mitigate  harm  to  the  environment  will  be  planned.  The  proposed  project  is 
expected to affect about 1,800 persons, including about 800 who will be permanently resettled. 
The TA will confirm the extent of resettlement required, assess other impacts on the livelihoods 
of  affected  persons,  and  prepare  compensation  and  rehabilitation  options  and  livelihood 
rehabilitation programs. An initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
10.  The scope of the project will be determined during implementation of the TA. The project 
is expected to comprise the following:  
(i)  Part A. The development of additional water resources in Xundian County, some 
100 km north of the main urban area of Kunming. This will increase the water 
storage capacity of Qingshuihai Lake by diverting water from the surrounding 
catchments of Banqiao River, Shiqiao River, Xintian River, and Tabizi River. 
(ii)  Part B. The conveyance of those water resources south to make them available 
as  an  urban  water  resource.  This  will  take  water  from  Qingshuihai  Lake  to 
Tongxin Gate, and then divert the water to the New Airport Economic Zone 
through the planned Jinzhongshan Reservoir, and to the Eastern Development 
Zone through the Songhuaba Reservoir.  
(iii)  Part C. Institutional development. This part will aim to strengthen the financial 
and managerial capacity of KMG in implementing the project, and operating and 
managing the facilities to be constructed under the project.  
 
11.  Complementary  investments  are  required  to  make  effective  use  of  the  new  water 
resource, and to prevent secondary pollution from increased wastewater. The Kunming Water 
Supply Company will construct water treatment plants and distribution networks for water supply 
in  the  New  Airport  Economic  Zone  and  the Eastern  Development  Zone.  This company  is 
expected to purchase raw water produced under the project. The Kunming Drainage Company 
will build wastewater treatment plants in the New Airport Economic Zone and the Eastern 
Development Zone to treat sewage generated under the project. A water treatment plant was 
constructed in 2005, and a wastewater treatment plant is planned for Xundian County. These 
complementary investments are included in relevant local development plans for 2006–2010, 
which  the  concerned  local  governments  have  prepared.  The  local  people’s  congress  has 
considered and approved the investments. The preliminary cost of the proposed project is 
CNY1,386 million ($173 million equivalent). The proposed ADB loan for $80 million will cover 
46% of project costs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The cost of the TA is estimated to be $800,000 equivalent. The Government has asked 
ADB to finance $600,000 equivalent. ADB’s TA funding program will provide a grant to finance 
the TA. The Government will finance the balance of $200,000 by providing counterpart staff,

4   
office  space,  furniture,  administrative  support  services  and  logistics,  preparation  of  the 
environmental impact assessment and resettlement plans, and necessary data (and translation 
of  such  data  into  English,  as  needed).  Detailed  cost  estimates  are  in  Appendix  3.  The 
Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  KMG will be the Executing Agency for the TA and the subsequent project. A project 
leading group, chaired by the vice mayor of Kunming, has been formed to provide guidance and 
support to project preparation. The project leading group includes the directors of the Kunming 
Development  and  Reform  Commission,  the Kunming  Finance  Bureau,  the  Kunming  Water 
Bureau  (KWB),  the  Kunming  Planning  Bureau,  the  Kunming  Water  Supply  Company,  the 
Kunming Environmental Protection Bureau, the Kunming Land and Resources Bureau, the Lake 
Dianchi Administration Bureau, the Administration Committee of Kunming Air Harbor Economic 
Zone, Xundian County, Songming County, and Guandu District.  
 
14.  A project management office (PMO) has been established within the KWB. The director 
of KWB has been appointed as the director of the PMO, which includes representatives at the 
vice director level from the Kunming Development and Reform Commission and the Kunming 
Finance  Bureau.  Representatives  from  other  relevant  bureaus,  including  the  Kunming 
Environmental  Protection  Bureau  and  the  Kunming  Land  and  Resources  Bureau,  will  be 
seconded to the PMO when the need arises. The PMO will ensure interagency coordination, as 
well as access by the consultants to reports, information, and data needed to implement the TA 
effectively.  This  will  include  assistance  in  organizing  environmental,  socioeconomic, 
resettlement, and other required surveys and consultations. The PMO also will be responsible 
for liaison with ADB during TA implementation, including making local arrangements for ADB 
missions to review TA progress. KMG will provide one experienced and qualified member of the 
PMO staff to work full time with the TA, in close coordination with the TA consultants.  
 
15.  The TA will require 14 person-months of international consulting services and 37 person-
months of domestic consulting services. The international consultants will provide expertise in 
water  resources  management  (6  person-months),  social  analysis  (2  person-months),  dam 
engineering  (1.5  person-months),  environmental  impact  assessment  (1.5  person-months), 
financial  analysis  and  financial  management  assessment  (1  person-month),  institutional 
analysis (1 person-month), and project economic analysis (1 person-month). The domestic 
consultants will have expertise in civil engineering (6 person-months), resettlement (5 person-
months), water resources (5 person-months), community participation and poverty (4 person-
months), environmental impact assessment (4 person-months), financial analysis (4 person-
months), economic analysis (3 person-months), institutional development (3 person-months), 
cost engineering (2 person-months), and mechanical engineering (1 person-month). ADB will 
select and engage consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on Use of Consultants and 
other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  selection  and  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. The quality- and cost-based selection method, using simplified technical proposal 
procedures, will be followed. The consultants may procure equipment through shopping in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines.  Upon  completion  of  the  TA,  equipment 
procured  under  the  TA  will  be  transferred  to  the  EA.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants are in Appendix 4.  
  
16.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months, from October 2006 to March 2007. The 
major reports required from the consultants are (i) an inception report describing the detailed

5
work program within 1 month of TA commencement, (ii) an interim report within 3 months of TA 
commencement, (iii) a draft final report within 5 months of TA commencement, and (iv) a final 
report 4 weeks after receiving comments from the Government and ADB on the draft final report. 
Tripartite meetings will be held with the Government, ADB, and the consultants to discuss the 
TA reports, which will be prepared in English and translated into Chinese. Workshops for a 
broad group of stakeholders will be held at TA inception, as well as following the presentation 
and Government review of the draft final report. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Kunming Qingshuihai 
Water Supply Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

A.  Links to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the People Republic of China (PRC):  
 
By making additional water resources available for urban use, the proposed project will contribute to poverty reduction 
by facilitating economic development in Kunming City, and by improving the well-being and health conditions of 
residents in newly urbanized areas in Kunming. Employment opportunities during construction and operation of project 
facilities also will be provided.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
A poverty and social analysis for the project will be carried out during the feasibility study to (i) summarize the causes 
of poverty, (ii) identify the poor in the project areas, (iii) quantify how the project will help to reduce poverty, and 
(iv) incorporate other social measures within the scope of project implementation. The social dimensions will address 
(i) a demand and needs assessment of the targeted population; (ii) gender analysis; (iii) affordability; (iv) core labor 
standard and social risks; and (v) social safeguards, including ethnic minority issues. The analysis performed also will 
include a quantification of employment benefits (disaggregated by gender, and between poor and non-poor). Further, 
the assessment will identify relevant indicators of poverty and social dimensions for incorporation into the project 
performance monitoring system (PPMS). 
 
The poverty and social analysis will be conducted following guidance from the ADB’s Handbook for Incorporation of 
Social Dimensions in the Projects, Handbook for Poverty and Social Analysis, and Handbook for Integrating Poverty 
Impact on Economic Analysis of Projects. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
A stakeholder analysis and public consultation will be an integral part of the poverty, social, environmental, and 
resettlement assessments. The Executing Agency, Implementing Agency, design institutes, and consultants will carry 
out public consultations during preparation of the environmental impact assessment (EIA) and resettlement plans 
(RP). Main stakeholders include government departments and officials at provincial, municipal, and county levels, 
managers and employees of the Implementing Agency, and project beneficiaries (urban residents, new migrants, and 
project-affected people). Further stakeholder analysis will be carried out as necessary during technical assistance (TA) 
implementation.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
A participatory approach will be required for preparing poverty and social analysis, EIA, and RPs. The TA will design a 
participation  strategy  to  be  undertaken  before  and  during  construction.  The  participatory  strategy  will  include 
consultation on arrangements for public information disclosure, compensation and resettlement issues, and the 
environmental management plan. 
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Gender analysis will be part of the poverty and social assessment to define where, when, and how gender issues will 
be addressed during the project design, implementation, and monitoring. The poverty and social assessment during 
the project design will identify strategies, mechanisms, and components for addressing gender concerns.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Review of Medium- and Long-Term Plans 
 
1.  The project consultants will review and analyze the medium- and long-term sector plans for 
water supply and wastewater management within Kunming municipality. This will be carried out in 
the  context  of  broader  integrated  water  resources  management  and  the  Kunming  urban 
development plan. Based on the review of these plans, the consultants will assess the Kunming 
municipal  government  (KMG)  policies  and  strategies  for  water  resources  management  and 
pollution control to ensure that a comprehensive approach has been adopted, and all appropriate 
options have been considered on a least-cost basis. The consultants will recommend changes in 
the sector plans to make them more responsive to the development objectives of Kunming, and to 
provide an improved water environment to all its residents, including vulnerable groups.   
 
2.  The scope of work included in the proposed project, as detailed in the domestic feasibility 
study report (FSR), will be analyzed in the context of the Kunming urban development plan and the 
sector plans (para. 1). Reference will be made, as appropriate, to national and provincial sector 
policies and guidelines on planning, management, and financing of water supply projects. Value-
added  recommendations  will  be  made  on  the  suitability  of  the  proposed  project  to  fulfill  the 
objectives of the medium- and long-term sector plans. Where necessary, the consultants will 
recommend changes to the scope of the project.  
 
B.  Policy Dialogue-Related Activities 
 
3.  In relation to the continuing policy dialogue between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and the People’s Republic of China (PRC), in conjunction with ADB’s lending program for the 
urban  development  sector,  the  consultants  will  prepare  notes  for  policy  dialogue,  based  on 
discussions with the Yunnan provincial government and KMG. These notes, which will help define 
the  policy  framework  for  project  implementation,  will  cover  (i)  integrated  water  resources 
management,  (ii)  water  sector  institutional  arrangements,  (iii)  water  pricing  as  a  demand 
management tool, and (iv) private sector involvement. The consultants will review ADB’s water 
policy1 and Urban Sector Strategy,2 and relevant review reports.3 Further, they will ensure that the 
proposed project design covers the key action items indicated in these strategic documents. The 
consultants  also  will  identify  any  other  policy  issues  that  should  be  included  in  future  policy 
dialogue between ADB and the PRC, or that are potentially significant to project implementation. 
Policy notes will be included in the interim, draft final and final reports, as appropriate. 
 
C.  Technical Aspects 
 
4.  The consultants will review the project proposals, FSR, environmental impact assessment 
(EIA), and resettlement plans (RP) prepared by the Executing Agency (EA) for the proposed 
project, and other related reports used to substantiate the analyses of the FSR. The consultants 
will review the alternative assessment conducted by KMG and confirm that the best alternative has 
been proposed in terms of (i) technical appropriateness; (ii) cost effectiveness; and (iii) social, 
environmental, and resettlement impacts. Particular attention will be given to the water demand 
forecasts used in the domestic FSR, as well as the methods and assumptions used in their 
derivation. Based on the reviews, the findings of the domestic FSR will be confirmed and/or 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2001. Water for All. The Water Policy of the Asian Development Bank. Manila. 
2  ADB. 1999. Urban Sector Strategy. Manila 
3  Most  documents  are  available  in  the  water  and  urban  development  websites:  www.adb.org/water  and 
www.adb.org/urbandev.

12  Appendix 4 
 
modified, as required. Where details are lacking, the consultants will carry out the necessary 
studies. 
 
5.  The consultants will  
(i)  review the reasonableness of assumptions made in assessing future water demand 
in the newly urbanized areas of Kunming and, as a result of this review, determine 
whether the scope, size, and phasing of the proposed project are reasonable;  
(ii)  examine plans for water treatment and construction of water networks in the newly 
urbanized  areas  of  Kunming  that  will  be  served  by  the  project  to  ensure  that 
assumed  benefits  from  the  project  can  be  realized  in  a  timely  manner  without 
endangering the financial viability of the Implementing Agency (IA) and its capacity 
to repay debt; and identify any inconsistencies between the timing of the project and 
complementary urban water supply investments in the inception report;  
(iii)  confirm  the  reasonableness  of  the  investigations  conducted  and  calculations 
undertaken to assess the reliable yield of proposed water sources;  
(iv)  review, assess, and verify the technical feasibility of the proposed solutions and 
facilities proposed for the individual project components as included in the domestic 
FSR, including reservoirs and dams (e.g., types, construction material, heights, and 
regulation volumes), conveyance systems, and measures to ensure obligations to 
maintain base river flows;  
(v)  review  the  technical  aspects  of  proposed  soil  conservation  and  environmental 
protection works to ensure these can meet their objectives;  
(vi)  review and/or develop design criteria and standards for dam construction, water 
offtakes, and conveyance systems; review outline designs; and verify the planning 
horizon for project facilities and other facilities they will interface with to ensure 
planning assumptions are compatible;  
(vii)  estimate quantities of major civil works items and schedules of major items of plant 
and equipment, including instrumentation and control systems;  
(viii)  develop unit rates for civil works items, manufacturers’ budget quotations for major 
plant  items,  and  detailed  construction  estimates,  following  ADB  guidelines  and 
standards,  and  using  costing  models  that  incorporate  ADB’s  requirements  for 
physical and price contingencies and interest during construction;  
(ix)  prepare  detailed  financial  plans,  disbursement  schedule,  and  implementation 
schedule,  and  propose  procurement  packages  and  a  procurement  plan  in 
accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines;  
(x)  develop environmental monitoring systems to ensure the reliability of quality in the 
water to be supplied from the project facilities; and  
(xi)  estimate consulting services inputs needed for project implementation, including 
institutional development, engineering design, and construction supervision over the 
project implementation period. 
 
D.  Environmental Impact Assessment 
 
6.  To ensure the proposed project complies with ADB’s Environment Policy, the consultants 
will  (i)  review  the  EIA  prepared  by  a  designated  local  environment  institute  for  each  project 
component; (ii) prepare supplementary information and/or mitigation measures to the EIA, if the 
EIA is not in compliance with ADB’s requirements; (iii) prepare a draft summary EIA (SEIA) and a 
draft environmental management plan (EMP); and (iv) support KMG in finalizing the EIA, SEIA, and 
EMP. This work, which will be conducted in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy and 
Environmental Assessment Guidelines, will identify (i) positive and negative environmental impacts,

Appendix 4  13 
and quantify them; (ii) environmental risks relevant to each component during construction and 
operation; and (iii) mitigation measures and an environmental management program for each 
component. The consultants will review and build on the environmental assessments completed in 
the  domestic  EIA.  In  addition,  they  will  help  the  Government  prepare  and  undertake  public 
consultations  required  by  ADB  and  the  Government.  The  consultants  will  coordinate  the 
environmental and social analysis to ensure the best use of resources and the effectiveness of 
planned consultations. The environmental issues to be considered will include  
(i)  impact of increasing the area of submerged land resulting from reservoir expansion 
and construction;  
(ii)  water balance and the pattern of water use in the catchments whose water will be 
diverted to Qingshuihai Lake;  
(iii)  impact on the downstream areas that will have less water;  
(iv)  secondary pollution resulting from additional wastewater in the urban areas;  
(v)  potential nuisance from the construction and operation of proposed facilities;  
(vi)  soil conservation in farming practices in conjunction with water sources protection, 
and  recommend  an  approach  for  environmental  sustainable  farming  practices, 
training, and design to integrate water and soil conservation;  
(vii)  resettlement;  
(viii)  construction techniques; and  
(ix)  material impacts on water quality.          
 
E.  Financial Analysis and Financial Management Assessment 
 
7.  The consultants will extend the financial analysis presented in the domestic FSR. The 
purpose is to assess the financial and fiscal sustainability of the ensuing project, and financial 
viability  of  the  IA.  The  financial  analysis  and  the  financial  management  assessment  will  be 
undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of 
Projects.  
 
8.  The financial management assessment will be completed by the interim report. For this 
assessment, the consultants will  
(i)  use the Standard Project Cost Table (COSTAB) or similar models to analyze and 
summarize project costs;  
(ii)  conduct a financial management assessment of the EA and IA, including review of 
accounting and administrative capabilities, the internal control systems, and internal and 
external  auditing  procedures;  and  develop  an  action  plan  to  rectify  gaps  and 
weaknesses identified using ADB’s Financial Management Assessment Questionnaire;  
(iii)  establish financial objectives and targets for the IA and prepare financing plans and 
projections, including income statements, balance sheets, cash-flow statements, and 
other relevant financial statements in normal terms, for operations for the 15 years after 
project completion;  
(iv)  examine the availability of local counterpart funds, and assess the liquidity of KMG for 
different levels of borrowing;  
(v)  compute in real terms the financial internal rate of return and the average incremental 
cost in financial terms for the project; and  
(vi)  propose commercial cofinancing and private sector involvement in the financing plan as 
appropriate.

14  Appendix 4 
 
F.  Economic Analysis 
 
9.  The consultants will work with economic analysts in the appointed design institutes to 
design  and  appraise  each  component  of  the  project  according  to  PRC’s  standards  for  the 
economic analysis of projects. The analysis should be consistent with ADB’s Guidelines for the 
Economic Analysis of Projects, recent retrospective reports on economic analysis, and relevant 
technical notes published by ADB’s Economics and Research Department. 
 
10.  The consultants will review the investment program under the long- and medium-term 
sector development plans. The justification of the investment program should be based on meeting 
broad social goals at least cost. Analysis of the goals should include a review of the process of 
establishing them, the role of public participation and input, and public support for the resulting 
goals. Given the goals, the analysis then should consider how to achieve them at least economic 
cost.  The  analysis  should  aim  to  identify  enhancements  or  improvements  to  policies  and 
institutions to attain the goals. Policy analysis also should cover user charges, though they should 
be considered as a general policy tool, not merely for raising revenue. Further, the consultants will 
review and evaluate sources of funds for the investment program, including revenue, use charges, 
commercial credit, concession credit, and external assistance. 
 
11.  The economic analysis will include  
(i)  review and evaluate the standards or targets for ensuring the reliability of water 
resources; determine if existing standards or targets are economically and socially 
justified;  and  recommend  changes  as  needed  (e.g.,  should  more  efforts  be 
dedicated to demand management rather than provision of increased supplies);  
(ii)  conduct least-cost analysis covering policy and investment options; and identify the 
least-cost option to meet the standards or targets, as well as any recommended 
changes;  
(iii)  review tariffs for water and wastewater in accordance with ADB’s position on tariffs, 
as described in Technical Note #94 published by ADB’s Economics and Research 
Department, and elaborated in other related technical notes, covering, among other 
things, the extent and justification of any subsidies, helping the poor satisfy their 
basis  needs,  and  using  charges  to  encourage  efficient  use  of  resources;  and 
recommend changes to tariffs, as needed;  
(iv)  forecast demand for water based on projected tariffs, and use those forecasts and 
other relevant information to reassess the scale of the project; and recommend 
changes to tariffs based on the forecasts of existing tariffs and recommended tariffs, 
if any;  
(v)  use the forecasts of water demand to estimate the scale of investment in the project 
that minimizes the expected present value of current and future capacity costs, 
ensuring that the scale for the proposed project should balance the cost of present 
and future capacity expansions, as needed; and estimate the cost of any proposed 
deviations from the least-cost expansion plan; and 
(vi)  evaluate identified investments relative to other opportunities for public investments, 
based on standard benefit-cost analysis, to the extent feasible, as described in 
ADB’s Guidelines on Economic Analysis of Projects, recent retrospective reports on 
economic analysis, relevant technical notes published by ADB’s Economics and 
Research Department, and an analysis of poverty in the project’s areas; identify 
priorities for public investments and estimate of public support for the project, based 
social surveys; and evaluate how other priorities are being addressed. 
                                                 
4  ADB. 2004. Improving Urban Wastewater Tariffs and Management. Manila.

Appendix 4  15 
G.  Socioeconomic Analysis 
 
12.  The consultants will design and arrange a survey of project beneficiaries to cover each 
component area under the project (with the results disaggregated by gender and income group); 
estimate the number of project beneficiaries with income below the official poverty line in project 
component  areas;  conduct  affordability  analysis;  identify  vulnerable  groups,  including  ethnic 
minorities;  and  assess  any  impacts  and  recommend  mitigating  measures  required  for  these 
groups. 
 
13.  Using the survey results as appropriate, and by analyzing other relevant information, the 
consultant will  
(i)  undertake  poverty  assessment  of  targeted  population;  estimate  the  direct  and 
indirect project beneficiaries, disaggregated by gender, ethnicity, and income group; 
and evaluate project impact in reducing poverty;  
(ii)  undertake affordability analysis, willingness to pay for the services, and provide pro-
poor design to address the need of vulnerable groups and people living below 
poverty line;  
(iii)  undertake  social  analysis  following  ADB’s  Handbook  on  Poverty  and  Social 
Analysis5 as a guide;  
(iv)  assess and evaluate the potential of the project to affect significantly and adversely 
the  local  community  members,  including  women,  ethnic  minorities,  and  other 
vulnerable groups; and propose mitigation measures in accordance with ADB’s 
Involuntary  Resettlement  policy,  OM  Section  F2  on  Involuntary  Resettlement,6 
Policy on Indigenous Peoples, and OM Section F3 on Indigenous Peoples; 7  
(v)  collect and analyze health data, including the incidence of morbidity and mortality 
due to waterborne diseases;  
(vi)  review the arrangements and procedures for involving the targeted population in 
project  design  and  implementation;  develop  a  tailored  information  and  health 
education  campaign;  and  prepare  a  participatory  strategy  to  promote  public 
awareness and participation to be undertaken before and during the construction;  
(vii)  identify ethnic minorities, assess and evaluate project impacts on ethnic minorities, 
and propose mitigation measures in accordance with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous 
Peoples; and prepare a report, including social safeguards and other social risks, 
such as ethnic minorities;  
(viii)  undertake gender analysis and develop strategy to maximize project impact on 
women following ADB’s Gender Checklist for Water Supply and Sanitation,8 as well 
as use ADB’s Gender and Resettlement Checklist9 to identify and address gender-
related involuntary resettlement impacts;  
(ix)  develop indicators on poverty, health, and social impact to be incorporated in the 
project  performance  monitoring  system  (PPMS),  as  well  as  the  design  and 
monitoring framework; and  
(x)  prepare a report that addresses the issues, including (a) contribution of project in 
reducing poverty; (b) methodology in poverty and social analysis; (c) stakeholder 
analysis and participation strategy; (d) strategy to maximize impacts on women; (e) 
need and demand of the targeted population; (f) affordability analysis; (g) health 
                                                 
5  ADB. 2001. Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis: A Working Document. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2003. Operations Manual, Section F2/BP: Involuntary Resettlement. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2005. Operations Manual. Section F3/BP. Indigenous Peoples. Manila.   
8  ADB. Gender Checklist: Water Supply and Sanitation. Manila. 
9  ADB. Gender Checklist: Resettlement. Manila.

16  Appendix 4 
 
benefit  of  the  project;  and  (h)  social  safeguards  and  social  risks,  such  as 
resettlement, labor, ethnic minorities, and other risks and/or vulnerabilities. 
 
H.  Resettlement 
 
14.  The consultants will confirm the extent of resettlement required, and assess other impacts 
that the project will have on the livelihoods of affected persons (AP). The consultants will review 
the domestic draft RPs and identify any modifications required to comply with relevant PRC laws 
and regulations, as well as ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement10 policy and OM Sections F2 on 
Involuntary Resettlement. When preparing the RPs, the consultants will use ADB’s Handbook on 
Resettlement as a guide. In particular, the consultants will  
(i)  evaluate the relevant local resettlement experience;  
(ii)  as part of the socioeconomic baseline survey, identify permanent and temporary 
socioeconomic impacts resulting from land acquisition, and changes in land use or 
restrictions  of  access  to  assets  and  common  property  resources;  prepare  an 
inventory of affected assets and livelihoods and censuses, as are necessary to meet 
ADB  requirements;  and  quantify  impacts  to  APs  and  ensure  that  gender  and 
resettlement  issues  are  identified  and  addressed,  using  ADB’s  Gender  and 
Resettlement Checklist as a guide;  
(iii)  using  the  survey  results,  define  categories  of  impact  and  eligibility  of  APs  for 
compensation; and prepare an entitlement matrix covering compensation for all lost 
assets and income, and assistance to achieve full replacement costs for lost assets, 
income, and livelihood;  
(iv)  review the institutional arrangement to distribute resettlement compensation;  
(v)  help  the  EA  and  IA  refine  the  RPs,  giving  particular  attention  to  budgets, 
implementation  schedules,  grievance  procedures,  and  arrangements  for  internal 
and external monitoring and evaluation;  
(vi)  help the EA initiate a participatory process for RP preparation by preparing and 
carrying out a consultation and participation plan, ensuring that APs are informed 
and consulted about compensation and resettlement options, including livelihood 
restoration  programs,  measurement  of  losses,  detailed  asset  valuations, 
entitlements and special provisions, grievance procedures, timing of payments and 
displacement schedule; and assist the EA in documenting consultation with APs, 
listing events, people consulted, documents disclosed, and timing of disclosure in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Public  Communications  Policy;11 and  summarizing  the 
issues raised, agreed actions, and improvements resulting from the consultation;  
(vii)  document  in  the  RPs  the  extent  to  which  the  project  design  has  avoided  or 
minimized land acquisition and displacement of people and businesses; identify 
potential impoverishment risks and vulnerable groups, including those experiencing 
major impacts through loss of assets and those with low income, and develop 
mitigation measures; and ensure consultations with APs are documented in the 
RPs;  
(viii)  assess stakeholders’ concerns and consider possible changes in the project design 
to minimize resettlement impacts; and assist the EA to finalize, disclose, and get 
Government endorsement of the RPs before submission to ADB for review and 
approval;  
(ix)  assess whether the compensation standards for all types of assets, crops, and trees 
are based on replacement value, and discuss in detail the valuation methodology 
                                                 
10  ADB. 1998. Handbook on Resettlement: A Guide to Good Practice. Manila. 
11  ADB. 2005. Public Communications Policy. Manila.

Appendix 4  17 
used; ensure that the resettlement budget is sufficient to acquire the land and 
implement the RPs; help the EA to prepare a detailed resettlement schedule that is 
linked to the overall project schedule; include a plan for internal monitoring and 
supervision,  and  a  plan  for  periodic  external  monitoring  and  evaluation  by  an 
independent agency in the RPs; update the RPs based on detailed design if they 
are prepared based on the domestic FSR, and disclose the updated RPs to APs 
before submitting them to ADB for review and approval;  
(x)  prepare a summary RP; and  
(xi)  provide  guidance  in  the  preparation  of  resettlement  information  booklet(s),  and 
agree on appropriate arrangements for public disclosure of the RPs to APs. 
 
I.  Institutional Analysis, Capacity Building, and Training 
 
15.  The  consultants  will  review  and  assess  the  institutional  capacity  of  relevant  local 
government departments and the designated IA to undertake the roles they have been assigned 
under the project. Based on the assessment, the consultants will  
(i)  identify deficiencies and prepare recommendations to strengthen the departments’ 
and/or agencies’ institutional and technical capability, encompassing administrative, 
management, organizational, technical (i.e., monitoring and evaluation, economic 
analysis),  and  financial  aspects;  and  develop  outline  terms  of  reference  for  a 
capacity building and institutional development, and internal and external training 
programs;  
(ii)  develop corporate management arrangements and finance procedures for the IA, 
particularly the preparation and implementation of improved organizational structure 
and human resources plan, full financial analysis of the proposed IA to verify its 
financial  status  and  ensure  its  financial  health,  budgeting,  and  business  plan 
development, management information system, and internal and external training 
programs;  
(iii)  design and prepare a program, including studies and training of managers and staff 
responsible for service delivery, to strengthen their capacity to efficiently implement, 
operate,  and  maintain  the  facilities  and  techniques  to  be  introduced  under  the 
ensuing project, and to ensure sustainability of project benefits; and  
(iv)  propose appropriate institutional arrangements and a related policy framework for 
private sector participation in the water sector. 
 
J.  Project Performance Monitoring System 
 
16.  The consultants will undertake a structured problem analysis, prepare a problem tree, and 
derive  a  design  and  monitoring  framework  in  consultation  with  government  agencies  and 
concerned project stakeholders. The framework will aim to facilitate (i) conceptualization of the 
proposed project design; (ii) monitoring of project implementation; and (iii) evaluation of project 
benefits and impacts, emphasizing enhanced participation of beneficiaries and stakeholders. The 
consultants will develop a PPMS that includes the content and format of the progress reports, and 
ensures that the beneficiaries also undertake monitoring and evaluation.
